div.p: 1. Monday. V:45. It being all Saints day, Mr Ironside, who is a Roman Catholic gave his School boys a Holiday, and Charles spent the day at home. At the Office, Mr Edmond Jennings Lee, Clerk of the U.S. Circuit Court for the County of Alexandria, brought returns of the Causes pending in that Court, required by a Resolution of the Senate at their last Session— He thought there should be some compensation for the work, which not being authorised to grant, I advised him to suggest for the consideration of the Senate, with his return. I had two applications for the appointment of Watchmen, to the new Public Building in which the Offices of the Department are kept— I was occupied the whole Evening in adjusting my household Accounts which owing to my absence have run three Months without examination— The President returned this Evening to the City.

2. V:15. I am making an Abstract of the Regulations of the several States of this Union upon the subject of weights and Measures. Shortly after the Resolution of the Senate passed 3. March 1817. requiring a Report from the Secretary of State on this subject, Mr Rush wrote a circular to the Governor’s of the States requesting of them returns of the Legislative measures of their respective States on this head— The answers to this Circular, are yet very imperfect—two States, Georgia and Tennessee have not been heard from at all. Maryland has only promised an answer; and from several other States short abstracts from their Statutes have only been transmitted. As the Session of Congress draws near, my apprehensions increase that either I must make a very lame Report, or postpone it over again to another Session— I wrote this day to the Governors of Maryland, and Georgia requesting again returns from them— There is a Law requiring that the Secretary of State should from time to time procure the Statutes of the Several States, and yet I believe there is not at the Department nor indeed in Washington a single complete set of the Laws of any one State in the Union. I must make an attempt to remedy this as far as it can be remedied. In this City the weights and measures are regulated by the Laws of Maryland, and Ordinances of the City Legislature. A Mr Leonard is the Standard keeper, and Scaler of weights and Measures— I called upon him this Morning to make some enquiries of him; but he was abroad; employed upon the duties of his office, and had his weights and measures with him— Called at the President’s, and found Mr Crawford and Mr Wirt with him— They were conversing with him upon the result of the Court Martial on the Cadets at West-Point, in which the Court decided that they had no jurisdiction, & thus that the Cadets were not subject to the Articles of War. After one such decision by the Court Martial
an elaborate opinion of the Attorney-General was taken and approved by the President, and transmitted to the Court with orders to reassemble, and reconsider the question which they did, and adhered to their former decision. This is the second instance within twelve months of sending to a Court Martial an opinion of the Attorney General to induce them to revise their judgment; which in both cases they have refused. I think the same result may almost always be expected. Crawford thought that Court-Martials were bound to abide by the opinions of the Attorney-General, sanctioned by the President— I very much incline to think that in this instance the decision of the Court Martial was right, and it is remarkable that the whole tenour of Wirt’s argument which is learned and ingenious, is in direct opposition to his conclusion— It is indeed one of those questions upon which the Judges of the Supreme Court of the United States or the twelve Judges of England might be equally divided— The investigation of this affair has however satisfied me that the Cadets ought not to be subject to the Articles of War; but to a system of discipline more suited to their circumstances as youths and Students, combining part of the Articles of War, with other Regulations adapted to the good management of Seminaries of Instruction. I suggested this idea which was well received, and may be further considered hereafter— But the difficulty lies in the present case itself— These Cadets five in number have now been nearly a year under arrest; and suspended from attendance on the course of Instruction at the Academy. The Court-Martial by which one of them was tried, decided, not upon an objection made by them, but on a question raised by the Court itself that it was not competent to try them— To discharge and restore them without censure would be to place them in a very awkward relation with the Superintendent at the head of the Institution Major Thayer, whose veracity they attempted to impeach by testimony improperly admitted by the Court Martial— To dismiss them would be a harsh measure, as their offence if any was not of an aggravated nature; as they have never declined, but have rather courted a trial; and the President said he had received a Letter from the father of one of the Cadets, Loring, complaining of the great hardship of the case. Crawford was for dismissing them at once, by the discretionary power of the President. But neither Mr Wirt nor the President, appeared to be prepared for so decisive a measure as that— I had difficulty in restraining myself from opposing it, but I forebore— At these consultations I have frequent occasion to observe that Crawford advances opinions, so preposterous, that it is difficult to impute them to perfectly correct motives— The dismission of these Cadets would not only be an act of extreme injustice, but certainly an act highly unpopular on the part of the President. Crawford feels this, though he is perhaps not conscious, that it infects his opinions and advice; but he takes special care to recommend no measure which could bring a breath of unpopularity upon his own Department. He advances other opinions, more for the sake of being in collision with mine, than from any special attachment to them as his own— I ought to lay it down as a rule to myself never to oppose any opinion advanced by Crawford, in the Cabinet, when I know, that without my opposition the President will not adopt it— Perhaps it would be well to extend the rule to what is said by any other member of the administration—to avoid every conflict of opinion, when it is unnecessary to affect the result, and to leave absurdity to die a natural death. The President said that Thayer was an excellent Officer, and that the Academy at West-Point was in a very flourishing condition. There was some desultory Conversation about Captain Partridge, against whom Crawford told several very ugly anecdotes, and about Charles Collins, Collector of Bristol Rhode-Island, who he says is undoubtedly concerned in the Slave-trade, though legal proof of it cannot be obtained— Crawford said he had done nothing yet about Mrs Bagot’s silks from Canton, though at his request I had given my opinion that they ought to be admitted without payment of duties. He said he thought if admitted at all it should be upon condition that they should be re-exported. This gave rise to a discussion, in which I stated my opinion that the allowance of the privilege to foreign Ministers, of free admission of Articles for their own or family use, ought to be as liberal as possible,
so long as there is no suspicion of fraud or bad faith, and that the indulgence ought to stop the instant that abuse or even suspicion of abuse should begin. He admitted there was no cause for suspicion in the present case, but said there was no Law for allowing the exemption— The President said it was by the Law of Nations: and directed that the silks should be admitted— Crawford in his argument to support the principle that the Court Martial ought to be bound by the opinion of the Attorney-General, had laid it down as a general rule that when the opinion of that Officer is asked on a point of Law by a competent authority, it ought to be taken by them as conclusive; because if they could come to a decisive opinion against it, they ought not to take the opinion at all. It struck me that Crawford ought to have applied his principle to his own practice— He ought not to have referred this case to me for my opinion, or he ought to have abided by my opinion when given—which it was very explicitly. The object itself is so trifling, and the principle I assume at once so fair and safe that I cannot very easily account for his disregard of my opinion after asking it, but from the belief that his own opinion inclined the other way; but that he was willing to haggle with a foreign Minister about the duties upon two or three pieces of silk, and at the same time to put all the littleness, and all the petty trouble of the discussion upon me— He said that under the colour of this permission, other silks than those ordered for Mr Bagot, might be delivered with them— I said it would be proper to require of Mr Antrobus to specify the identical Silks imported by order of Mr Bagot; and to limit the Collector to the free admission of them only— He had objections even to this— He said Antrobus might answer that he did not know. I said Mr Astor, the importer must know, and might be required to state— There were also two other cases of applications from Antrobus, which I had referred to Crawford, who has decided against one of them, and who said he should decide probably against the other, and in both instances rightly— The President said Astor had made the same offer to him to import any Articles for him from China, and Mrs Monroe, had ordered some Teas; upon which of course the duties would be paid— Crawford said he had only ordered some plants of the Tick-tree, which he thought would grow in Louisiana—I had understood him the other day, to say the Tea-Plant— We were at the President’s till past three; so that I was only a half an hour at my Office— Mr and Mrs Crawford paid us an Evening visit, and W. S. Smith was here— Cardelli gave a lesson to the children.

3. V: In the course of my enquiries to prepare the Report to the Senate upon weights and measures, I came naturally to the question what was their condition in this District— In Washington they are regulated by the By-Laws of the Corporation— The Mayor was authorised to procure a complete set according to the standard used in Maryland, and a Sealer is appointed who is required once every three Months to enter every Store shop or place where goods are bought and sold and examine the weights and measures— A Mr Leonard holds this Office now, who has a shop near my house. I called there yesterday and several times this Morning to see him and his Standards; but he was absent in the performance of his duties. I left a request to see him to-morrow morning— I was at the Office of Mr Nourse the Register of the Treasury on some private concern of mine, and enquired of him whether any Instructions had ever been given to the Revenue Officers of the United States, with regard to the weights and measures used by them— He thought there were none, but promised to make enquiry— In analyzing the answers from the Governors of the States to the circulars requesting information of their respective Regulations, I find them still so imperfect; and questions connected with the subject multiply upon me in such a manner, that I feel the want of another year at least to make a better Report than I shall be able to prepare for the ensuing Session of Congress. But on the other hand this will be the third Session since the Report was called for by the Senate, and there is some impatience both in Congress and in the Public Mind, for something to be done by Congress, under their authority to regulate weights and measures— I shall therefore be obliged to make a report, unsatisfactory to myself, and which will probably prove so to Congress and to the Public. I received a Note from Baron Stakelberg the Swedish Chargé des Affaires, who arrived here last Evening
requesting me to appoint a time when I would see him— I directed an answer to be sent, fixing to-morrow at one O’Clock to see him at the Office. A Note from Mr Antrobus the British Charge d’Affaires enclosed a copy of a Letter from the Prince Regent to The United States of America—with a request for an Audience of the President to deliver it— The President directed me to appoint one O’Clock on Friday when he would receive them both. I spoke to the President, concerning Instructions to be given to R. Rush to propose again to the British Government, the Emperor of Russia, for the umpire, upon the disputed question upon the construction of the first Article of the Treaty of Ghent relating to the restoration of Slaves and other captured property— He directed me to prepare them. I also suggested to him the idea of asking Mr Rush and Mr Gallatin to procure and transmit the Laws and regulations by which the military Schools in France and England are governed: with a view to adopt those of them which may be found proper, for the Academy at West Point—which he approved. I asked him if he could not restore the five Cadets who had been so long suspended, with an expression of his disapprobation upon their conduct if he disapproved it; and also censuring the Court-Martial for admitting illegal testimony to the discredit of Major Thayer— He shewed me a Copy of a Letter from the Secretary of War, to Major Thayer, dated last January, declaring the President’s approbation of his conduct and his disapprobation of that of the Cadets; but directing the dismission of Bliss, the professor, against whom the Cadets complained, and that Thayer should restore them as soon as might be consistent with the Service— The President added that Major van Deventer the Chief Clerk in the War Department said that if this Letter had been communicated to the Cadets by Thayer when he received it, the whole affair would have subsided. But the Court Martial having been ordered, Thayer felt a delicacy at communicating the order.— The arrested Cadets are all young men of good character and promise— Their offence, though a serious one in reference to military discipline, was no offence at all, in the members of a civil, scientific institution. Such transactions should be treated with great lenity; and the whole of this affair shews the necessity of other Regulations for the Government of this Academy, than the mere Articles of War— Pleasonton was at my Office and explained to me the cause of his mistake in the case of Shaler’s Accounts. Forbes likewise called at the Office; and Mr Purviance who has just returned from an absence at Baltimore. I drafted a Letter, circular to the District Attorney’s, to procure the Statutes of the several States. My wife and the children spent the Evening at W. S. Smith’s.

4. V: I called twice this morning upon Mr Leonard the Sealer of weights and measures, and finally found him with his weights and measures, which are avoirdupoise weights, from 28 pounds to a half an ounce. A half-bushel peck, half peck, gallon and half gallon, dry measure—a Quart, Pint, half pint, Gill and half Gill wine measure, and a yard. They are of brass and copper—but no Beer measure, nor Troy weights— Leonard told me that the Alexandria Weights and Measures being from the Virginia Standards are not the same but smaller than these which are from the Standards of Maryland. Leonard had some old Troy weights of his own which I found upon trial were light— I sent for a tin Quart Pot and tried my Decanters till I found one that held exactly a Quart. I also weighed a Quart of Water, which I found to be 14724 grains or 2 Pounds 6 Ounces 13 Pennyweight and 12 Grains Troy weight, which is very nearly exact though the Scales I used were so course that less than a quarter of an ounce scarcely affected the balance— Baron Stakelberg, the Swedish Charge d’Affaires came to my Office at one, and I informed him the President had fixed the same hour to-morrow to receive him— Mr Manuel Torres also came at 2. O’Clock, and presented himself as Charge d’Affaires from the Government of Venezuela— He had a Credential Letter signed by the Vice-President Zea, addressed to all persons whom it might concern and constituting him Charge d’Affaires, in the absence of Don Lino Clemente—and a Letter of Instruction to him from the Secretary of State Roscio, referring to the Credential Letter as being perhaps informal
but directing him to use every exertion in his power to promote the cause of Venezuela, and its Independence, without infringing upon the Laws of Nations or of the United States— Torres left these papers, and a translation of them with me— I promised to lay them before the President, and told him I had no doubt I should be authorised to receive any communication from him which he might have occasion to make— Torres told me he had been constantly residing in the United States since the year 1796— I took his papers to the President, who said he had been informed that Torres would not be guilty of such misconduct as that of his predecessor Clemente; who he said had upon his return to Venezuela been imprisoned— Roscio told Commodore Perry that it was impossible for the Government of the United States to be more dissatisfied with the conduct of Clemente than that of Venezuela. I spoke to the President about the settlement of Perry’s account, and recommended the allowance of 1000 dollars, solicited for him by Decatur— The President authorised its allowance— I told him that Mr Poinsett had been consulted at Commodore Morris’s request, as to the expence, which might be necessary for such an agency at Buenos-Ayres—and he had mentioned 3000 dollars a year as adequate. The President, said Morris was a good officer and a discreet man; he had no doubt he would execute his commission well, and when he comes home, that he should have a liberal allowance— I mentioned Mr Fenwick’s claim of compensation for bringing Mr Forsyth’s despatches. He said he thought it would be proper to pay the expences of his passage, and to this place— Mr Anderson, the first Comptroller, and his Son, Pierce who is a Schoolmate of Charles’s spent the Evening with us, and Cardelli gave a drawing lesson to the children.

5. V:Forbes called upon me this morning to say he was going to Alexandria for some Articles arrived there in the New Packet from Boston— As I had two Chests shipped in the same vessel, he offered to look after them— He came back this Evening and said they would be sent up to-morrow. Mr Bowie of the house of Bowie and Kurtz of Georgetown, came to ask an answer to a Letter which they wrote me last February, concerning a claim which they have upon the Government, and a memorial to Congress— The paper was not to be found, and I requested Mr Bowie to send me a copy of his Letter. This accident of losing papers at the Office shews that a system of keeping them is one of the elements of order yet to be introduced into it. I directed Mr Brent to keep in future an entry of all the missing papers— At one O’Clock I went to the President’s— Antrobus came immediately afterwards and delivered to the President the Letter from the Prince Regent, announcing the birth of a Son, to the Duke of Cumberland, on the 27th. of May last— Baron Stakelberg shortly afterwards came, and I presented him to the President, to whom he made a short address, in the name of the king of Sweden, who he said had charged him to assure the President of the satisfaction with which he recollected the pleasure he had enjoyed in becoming acquainted with him in the year 1803. at Paris. The President answered in general terms, but took no notice of the personal compliment— After these ceremonials were performed, the President came from the Audience room into the Antichamber and had a conversation with me of an hour and a half upon the topics which it would be proper to introduce into his message, for the commencement of the ensuing Session of Congress. The first in point of importance he said was Spain, as with all the other European Powers our relations may be said to be upon the most friendly footing— Spain in withholding the ratification of the Treaty signed last February, had given notice that a Minister would be sent here to negotiate upon it— If that Minister should not arrive
before the Meeting of Congress, would it be proper to recommend a suspension of definitive measures until his arrival— I said, if the Hornet should not return before the Meeting of Congress, I thought it would be proper at the commencement of the Session, to communicate the papers of the Negotiation; to state the fact that her arrival might be expected at an early day and that a further communication would then be made— When she arrives the proper course of proceeding will be shaped according to the information to be received by her— But I thought nothing should be suspended to wait for the Spanish negotiator. When he comes, the ground with him should be changed— A direct and explicit refusal to negotiate upon any thing settled by the Treaty, and a call upon him to treat for the injury sustained by the United States, from the non-ratification within the limited and stipulated time seems to be the only proper course to be pursued— I still retained the opinion that the President should explicitly recommend to Congress an Act, authorising the immediate occupation of Florida— That a force should be sent sufficient to accomplish it without bloodshed, and a strong manifestation be given that the occupation is intended not as an act of hostility; but as the mere assertion of a right, unjustly withheld— The President fully concurred in this opinion, and said he thought it would be expected by the world— That all the principal powers of Europe had pronounced themselves against Spain upon the point of the ratification; and that if we should not act with promptitude, decision and vigour we should lose consideration in the eyes of the world; it would be taken for a symptom of weakness, and all the other Nations whose respect it is important to us to command would immediately take advantage of it against us— The President next spoke of General Jackson, and expressed some apprehension that he would again bring up the subject of the Report of the Committee of the Senate against him last Winter, and that it might lead to very unpleasant and distressing consequences: and he asked me whether I thought he ought to write to Jackson, and dissuade him from it. I said that as the friend of General Jackson, which it was certainly my wish to be, I should most earnestly wish that the subject of that Report should not be brought up again in the Senate by him or on his part, and although it might not be suitable for the President to enter into a correspondence with him to dissuade him from it, yet if there was any friend of the General’s in whom he had confidence, and who had influence over his mind, who could take the liberty of giving him advice, I thought it impossible he should be too urgent in giving it. My own belief was that if he had any thought of bringing it up again, it was from an apprehension that it would be brought up, by his enemies against him— The President said there were false stories in circulation, about Jackson, one of which Governor Worthington of Ohio had told him last Evening. It was that last Winter Jackson came to the President’s house, and asked to see him—was told by the Porter there was a Gentleman with him; enquired who it was; and was told it was Mr. Eppes; upon which he turned upon his heel, and said he would never set his foot in a house where such a fellow as Eppes was received— The President said there was no truth in this—enquiry had been made of his Porter, who did not even know Mr Eppes, and who declared that nothing like it had ever been said by Jackson— I said it was however certain that Jackson had been exasperated to the highest pitch against Eppes—that when he went from here last March it was with extreme difficulty he had been dissuaded from going to Eppes’s residence to challenge him, and that if the subject should be brought up again next Winter and he should be here, I was afraid nothing could prevent their fighting— He said he thought so, and it would be much to be lamented; but he also thought with me, that he could not directly interfere, to prevent it; especially as he had made an unsuccessful effort to reconcile Jackson with Scott— Jackson had told him he had no sort of doubt that Scott was a brave man—that he would not challenge him—that if when he wrote to him in consequence of the anonymous letter, Scott had answered him with candour that in a conversation at a private table, he had expressed opinions as he felt them without expecting that they would be reported to him; he would have thought no more of it—but to be charged with mutiny by his inferior officer—he did not see how it was possible for him to overlook it, without forfeiting his own self-respect— Other topics to be introduced into the message were postponed— But the President mentioned the Cadet Court-Martial again, and asked whether in disapproving the Sentence of the Court, he ought not to accompany it with some
further notice of displeasure— I said if he thought the proceedings of the Court were to be viewed in the light of misconduct to be punished, he might dismiss the Officers who composed it from the army; but if not, I thought it would be sufficient to disapprove in one word their proceedings, and to say no more on the subject. For to controvert their decision in a book—to argue against their opinion, would be perhaps descending to their level, and perhaps impair the dignity of the President’s Office. If it was to be mere reasoning against the sentence, they might say, well, the President’s opinion is one way, and ours is another—and the misfortune was that their’s was the effective opinion— To argue against that which he could not annul would be unprofitable waste of censure, and if more than mere official disapprobation was to be given, it ought to be by some act, and not by words— The President appeared to give assent to this— He said however that the arrested Cadets, had written a long and quite improper Letter to him— This was the first time I had heard of that— On returning from the President’s to my Office, I learnt that Mr Lowndes and B. O. Tayloe had arrived from England—and that Mr Stratford Canning had been appointed Minister here, in the room of Mr Bagot— While we were at dinner, Mrs Frye came in and informed my wife, that their Sister Mrs Hellen was at Georgetown. Mrs Adams went to see her. She came from Alexandria, with Mr T. Cook.

6. VI: My Journal absorbs so much time to give even the most summary abstract of Conversations with the President, that I shall be compelled to renounce it— At the Office this morning Mr Benjamin Ogle Tayloe came and brought me despatches from R. Rush, and a Letter from J. A. Smith; enclosing the Seal, which he has had engraved from the device which I sent him last Spring. Pleasonton came to make some enquiries concerning items of charges in Mr Gallatin’s Accounts— W. S. Smith and Frye successively came to consult with me concerning what it would be advisable for Mrs Hellen to do— I thought it necessary first to ascertain whether she would be advised— My time at the Office was so absorbed that I had none either to write, or to go over to the President’s— Mrs Adams went again this Evening to Georgetown to see her Sister, Mrs Hellen; and Cardelli gave a drawing Lesson to Charles and Mary—

7. VI:45. Attended at Mr M’Cormick’s church. He read prayers for the 22d. Sunday after Trinity; and the Communion Service, omitting the Litany; and his Sermon was from 1. Corinthians. XI.24. This do in remembrance of me. It was a further exhortation to attendance on this Christian Institution— It was my intention to have given much of the leisure of this day to the preparation of my Report on Weights and Measures; but first the newspapers of two days, and then Logarithmic calculations of the dimensions and contents of certain vessels of capacity swallowed up the whole day and Evening— I wrote not one line— My wife went to Georgetown and saw Mrs Hellen who is in a very bad state of health. She did not come home to dinner; but returned early in the Evening.

8. VI:30. I was yet unable this morning to extricate myself from the labyrinth of researches, concerning the calculation of contents of vessels of capacity. At the Office Dr Forsyth a Citizen of the United States, who has resided several years in the United States Venezuela, and is employed by the Patriot Government as Surgeon General of the forces came, and had a conversation of two hours with me, upon the concerns of the two Countries. He came from Angostura with Commodore Perry, and to this Country in the John Adams; and proposes to return to South-America, some time in December. He gave me much information concerning the state of affairs there; and shewed me a Letter from General Devereux to him written last June— He told me that Clemente’s conduct had been totally disapproved, particularly in his transactions with M’Gregor, and that when he left Angostura, Clemente was under arrest for having transcended his Instructions— That Dr Gual was now the judge of the Admiralty Court; and that he deeply regretted the part that he had taken with M’Gregor, in the affair of Amelia-Island. B. Blagge; a Son of S. Blagge of Boston—came to the Office to solicit a place— I passed the Evening uninterrupted in my chamber examining the Laws of the United States with reference to Weights and Measures.

9. VII Looking over the Laws of the United States with a view to the regulations in them concerning weights and measures, I observed a Law passed 15. September 1789. requiring that the Secretary of State should have all the Laws and Resolutions of Congress, recorded in Books to be provided for the purpose. No such record
has been kept for many years— I determined that this part of my duty should no longer be omitted, and gave Mr Brent some directions for carrying it into effect— I made also some preparations to have ready copies of documents to be communicated to both houses of Congress at the Commencement of the ensuing Session of Congress. Commodore Decatur came and introduced a Mr Allen to me, who he said had been acting Consul of the US. at Trieste. He brought me a Message of compliments from Count St. Julien, now Grand chamberlain to the Archduke at Milan— Mr B. L. Lear came from Mr Way, who he said had directed him to draw a Deed of the Estate I have agreed to purchase of him in F. Street. Cardelli gave a drawing lesson to the children, and I was inextricably immersed all the Evening in weights, measures, and logarithmic calculations.

10. V:30. For several days past until this morning, I had fallen into a lazy habit of not rising till day-light. I was this day more regular, but with little improvement of profitable occupation— At the Office President Brown of Dartmouth College brought me a Letter of Introduction from Dr Kirkland. He is an invalid, apparently deep in a consumption, and travelling with Mrs Brown, to South-Carolina, or Georgia, for a mild Winter Climate— They remain here only a few days. I called at the President’s; and he read to me the first sketches, of the Message he is preparing for the Commencement of the ensuing Session of Congress— They relate to Spain and the South-American Affairs; state the Circumstances of the failure of Spain to ratify the Treaty—the measures since taken by him; and recommend for the Consideration of Congress, whether we ought not to proceed, as if the Treaty had been ratified— The present state of the contest in South America, was spoken of in general terms, with the remark that success had generally attended the Patriots, who had maintained their cause in Buenos-Ayres, Chili and Venezuela, with increasing prospects of its ultimate establishment— These paragraphs were not finished; but he said he proposed to add that as it could not be expected that the struggle would be much longer protracted, the probability of its terminating in favour of the Independents had been considered, and proposals had been made to the British Government, for a recognition of the Independence of Buenos-Ayres, in concert; a proposition which might be offered at a suitable time to the other principal European powers— He said as the British Government had made known this proposition to Spain, it was no secret; and he thought it would be best to avow it explicitly; as it would take from those who wished to make a handle of the South-Americans against the administration, the ground from under them— I saw no adequate motive for objecting to this communication— And the President directed to have two copies made out of the Instructions given to Commodore Perry, and to his successor Morris. Besides these Subjects he spoke of the appointments to be made of District Judges for the Southern District of New-York and for Maryland— For the former there are several Candidates, all strongly recommended. For the latter he observed the recommendations in favour of Mr Bland had multiplied and strengthened; and among them was that of Mr Lloyd, who would probably come as one of the Senators from that State— It is obvious that Bland will be appointed, and that the President wished me to assent to the appointment— But I could not reconcile it to my sense of right and of duty— I told him that I was aware the pressure of influence in favour of Bland had much increased—that I thought too much of it had been used— I considered the imputations upon his integrity to be groundless— I believed him entirely honest— But I could not admit the principle upon which his appointment was urged to be absolutely necessary; as a vindication of his character, and the original objection against his appointment, that upon many of the most important causes pending before the Court, it was impossible that he should be impartial, still remained in force. The President said that these and some other considerations which were suggested had great weight and came for the present to no decision— He spoke also of the Law of the last Session of Congress authorising him to send to Africa, to which he thought Mr Crawford was for giving too extensive, and Mr Wirt too limited a construction— He himself considered it as giving him power to appoint and send two agents to the Coast of Africa, to reside there, and to make provision for the comfortable subsistence of the coloured people to be
transported thither by virtue of the act— I believe this may be done under the act, but observed that the Act itself had evidently passed without much consideration of its purport, and that it would be desirable that the whole subject should be revised by Congress— I submitted a question also upon a claim of Mr Gallatin, for an allowance from the contingent expenses of the Mission to France, for Office-Rent; which claim has also been made, by Mr. Campbell, Mr Graham and Mr Forsyth— No definitive determination— This Evening I began writing again upon the Report concerning weights and measures— My studies on this subject for many days have been at once very laborious and unprofitable.

11. IV:15. The weights and measures encroach upon my Journal; and although I rose thus early this Morning it was near Noon when I went to my Office, and the narrative of yesterday was left incomplete— Visits at the Office from Forbes, and from W. S. Smith with his Cousin John, son of Elizabeth Smith who first married John Smith brother of General Samuel Smith of Baltimore, and is now Mrs Thompson. She is here with her Son— Mary Hellen dined with her Guardian Mr T. Cook who after dinner came home with her; and brought her little half brother Walter Hellen, whom he left here to pass the Night— Mrs Adams went to see her Sister at Georgetown. Mr. Hyde de Neuville paid us an Evening visit—he arrived with his family, yesterday— Cardelli gave the children a drawing Lesson— My Evening was thus in a great measure taken from me; but I had already found myself so much overcome by weariness that I had been obliged to desist from writing.

12. IV:30. Employed the morning partly in writing on Weights and Measures, and brought up my Diary. But the hour of Noon arrived, and I could not as I intended go to the Capitol. Mr Brent was not at the Office, and the Office hours wasted away as usual. Dr Thornton came to explain to me that the copy-right Books ought not to be removed from the Patent Office; he said he had kept a Register of all the Books received for copy-right, and had kept all the books also perfectly safe— I desired him to send me the Register, and a list of the Books belonging to the Library of the Department which he has in his possession. The French Minister Hyde de Neuville came to the Office, and conversed with me concerning the state of our affairs with Spain. He thinks the Treaty will yet be ratified, of which I have no expectation. His reasons for expecting it, are nevertheless plausible. The Duke of San Fernando, who had been appointed to come to the United States has subsequently been appointed the Minister of foreign Affairs; and a Mr Campuzano is substituted as the person to come here. de Neuville adds, that the king of Spain had appointed a confidential Committee to examine the Treaty, and Report to him whether Onis had exceeded his Instructions— That they had reported entirely in favour of Onis and declared that he had in no respect transcended his Instructions— Onis was not received with much favour at Madrid; but is said to have been appointed as Minister to the Netherlands— De Neuville is much concerned for Roth and De Mun, who he is afraid have been lost at sea; in the Factor, a vessel which sailed on the 28th. of August from Havre, for New-York, and which is feared to have foundered on the passage— Forbes was at my house this Evening.

13. VII: I called this morning at the Office of Mr Nourse the Register of the Treasury, to enquire if he had received answers from the Collectors at Baltimore, Philadelphia, and New-York to the Letter, which I had requested him to write to them making enquiries concerning the weights and measures used at the Custom Houses, of those Ports. He had answers from New York and Baltimore, which suggested other questions, and I requested him to write a circular to one or more Collectors in all the original States of the Union asking them questions to ascertain the gravity of their weights and the capacity of their measures. He wrote such a circular accordingly; and brought it over to me. I suggested two or three alterations in its phraseology which he adopted— He sent also for a half bushel measure which had been sealed, both here and at Georgetown, and the dimensions of which I took— It was of the tub form—with a diameter at the top of 12.7 inches at the bottom of 11.2 inches and a depth of 9.7. and of course should contain 1089.3531562 solid inches, which is a gill more than a half bushel Winchester measure—but my admeasurement was very hasty and probably incorrect; and the measure itself was of wood not perfectly circular— Mr Wirt called at my Office, and took by direction of the President all the papers relating to the recommendation of Mr Bland to be the District Judge for Maryland— Wirt says that the appointment of Bland will be a general licence for
for the Pirates, and so considered by them. He says also that Mr Crawford has Letters informing him that there are now five privateers at Baltimore, fitted and ready to sail—and that Crawford who has hitherto favoured Bland’s appointment, now says it would be a questionable appointment. Wirt himself is very decided against it, but thinks it will nevertheless be made. Mr Nicholas Biddle of Philadelphia was at the Office— He said he came merely to have half an hour’s conversation with the President— I called at the President’s but he was not at home. This Evening I wrote little; but was again plunged into the whirlpool of weights and measures.

14. VII: I took up a Letter which I have received from Hassler with an account of his proceedings in a comparison of English and French measures of length; which I had at first carelessly read, but which I now found contained information of importance to be used in the preparation of my Report: it occupied all my Morning hours: but it was not wasted time— Cardelli was here, and shewed me Letters that he had received from Mr Jefferson, and Mr Madison— The former mentions a Quarry of white marble lately discovered in Virginia, equal to the finest marble of Carrara— I went with Mrs Adams to Mr Middleton’s at Kalorama; but Mrs Middleton was gone this Morning to Baltimore, to join her husband, who is returning from Philadelphia— They are going to pass the Winter in South Carolina; and Miss Bridon, a french young Lady, who is the governess to Mrs Middleton’s daughters, is to be married immediately to Mr Greuhm, the Prussian Minister resident— I walked home, and on the way returned several visits— At Madame de Neuville’s, we met first Mr and Mrs Lowndes, then Mr and Mrs Pleasonton, and lastly Mr. Charles Hay and a Mr Gouverneur. I called at Davis’s Hotel upon Mr Torres and Dr. Forsythe; the latter of whom I saw— Returning home, I had a visit from Mr Poletica the Russian Minister, just returned to the City from Philadelphia. He left Lomonossof sick of a fever at Baltimore— I told him in confidence of the instruction just despatched to R. Rush, to propose to the British Government to agree to apply to the Emperor of Russia, as the friendly Sovereign, to decide the question pending upon the Construction of the first Article of the Treaty of Ghent, according to the fifth Article of the Convention of 20. October 1818— Mr J. M. Forbes and John Law, were here at tea and for the Evening— W. S. Smith also.

15. V: Employed upon weights and measures— I have a wooden measure tub formed one end of which is a peck, and the other a Gallon dry measure, according to the standard of Maryland. It has one bottom within side— The peck is 7 1/2 inches deep, with a diameter at top of 10.1 inches and at bottom, of 9 inches— Its solid contents by these dimensions must be 537.801 cubic inches which is accurate in a very high degree. The Gallon is 4 3/4 with the top diameter 8.1. inch and the bottom 8.8. making its contents 266.5768 solid inches; both these vessels are correct as near as admeasurement can make them, in their agreement with the Winchester bushel. Mr T. Law paid me a morning visit— Stopped at the Patent Office and looked at Dearborn’s patent for a Steelyard. Examined also the drawing, model and specification, and looked at several other patented scales and steel-yards— There are several Volumes of the Transactions of the Royal Society of London, which I greatly want; but which it is impossible here to procure. I next passed at the Branch Bank, and enquired of their weights and Scales; with a view to weigh by them the Kilogramme, and other foreign Weights which I possess. I shall carry them for trial some day of this week. At Mr Nourse’s Office, I requested him to add one other request to his circular to the Collectors— That is to ask them to fill their bushels or half bushels with Water—Rain—River or Spring water, and to send accurately the weight contained in them— This was suggested to me in a Letter from Mr Steele the Collector of Philadelphia, in answer to the former enquiries from the Register, which I received yesterday— Mr Nourse made the addition to his Letter; which was ready printed, to be sent. At the Office, I had visits from Mr Mason, Consular Agent at St. Iago de Cuba, and from Mr N. Biddle who told me he should leave the City to-morrow Morning to return to Philadelphia. A note from the President requested my attendance at his house to-morrow at Noon with the other members of the Administration.
